Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Alexei Demchenko of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Missouri-St. Louis will develop effective approaches to stereocontrolled chemical glycosylation. This will be achieved by developing a reliable toolkit for studying the reaction pathways by which thioglycosides, glycosyl bromides, and the sulfonium salt intermediates form, isomerize and react. Successful completion of the proposed research lies in the project's contributions to basic and applied sciences developed at the interface of modern synthetic and mechanistic carbohydrate chemistries.

The broader impacts (and the key for success) of this program is the participation of undergraduate and graduate students, who will receive solid training in the research methods and achieve all key milestones in this project. The University of Missouri-St. Louis and the Demchenko laboratory are well positioned and strongly committed to broaden participation of research students from underrepresented groups, advance discovery of new reactions while promoting teaching, training and learning, and benefit society by developing stereocontrolled reactions for the synthesis of glycosidic linkages by means of which the most common organic molecules and many therapeutic agents connect.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From the building blocks of nature to disease-battling therapeutics and vaccines, carbohydrates have had a profound impact on evolution, society, economy, and human health. Numerous applications of these essential biomolecules in many areas of science and technology exist, foremost of which can be found in the area of development of therapeutic agents and diagnostic platforms. Although carbohydrate oligomers, oligosaccharides, are so desirable for biological and medical community, these molecules are very challenging targets for chemists because of the need for functionalization, protecting and leaving group manipulations, controlling anomeric stereoselectivity, etc. With participation of 14 post-docs, 14 doctoral, 6 Master’s, 35 undergraduate students, and 14 visitors to date, the Demchenko laboratory (Glycoworld) has been developing innovative tools that allow for expeditious synthesis of complex carbohydrates. The main result of this funding period is the development of the H-bond mediated aglycone delivery (HAD), a synthetic method that is likely to impact the entire field of carbohydrate synthesis.

The results of this project have been disseminated in 18 articles to date; the PI's students delivered 25 research posters and talks, and the PI delivered 35 invited lectures at universities and symposia. Seven graduate students (four women) and four undergraduates (all are women, three of whom are African Americans) have been supported from this Award. Of those who have graduated to date, all are employed in industry or academia. Further impact of this award derived from its educational component - development of new experiments for the undergraduate laboratory, an important direction in the PI's program

Modified by: Alexei V Demchenko
